Lattice stress modulation is an effective means to regulate the photocatalytic performance of materials. In this study, the TiO2-2.5 photocatalyst was successfully prepared using a simple NaBH4 treatment method, and its photocatalytic activity in the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) to benzaldehyde (BAD) was investigated. The results showed that compared to untreated TiO2, TiO2-2.5 significantly increases the conversion rate of BA to BAD up to 81.2 % within 6 h under the irradiation of a 300 W xenon lamp. Analysis by XRD, TEM, XPS, and UV–vis DRS revealed that the NaBH4 treatment introduced lattice stress and defects, altering the electronic structure and surface chemical environment of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its photocatalytic performance. Moreover, the decrease in activity of TiO2-2.5 during cyclic use is attributed to the strong adsorption of the reaction product BAD on the catalyst surface, which covers some of the active sites. This study provides valuable information for the defect regulation and photocatalytic performance enhancement of TiO2-based catalysts. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lattice stress TiO2 photocatalyst Defect regulation Photocatalytic selective oxidation Benzyl alcohol Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The photocatalytic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes represents a cornerstone transformation in modern organic synthesis, critically enabling the installation of aldehyde functionalities that serve as versatile intermediates for pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and fine chemical production [1–4]. While conventional stoichiometric oxidants raise environmental concerns, photocatalysis has emerged as a sustainable alternative by harnessing light energy to drive selective transformations under mild conditions [5–8]. This green methodology leverages photoexcited catalysts to mediate electron transfer processes while minimizing hazardous byproducts and energy consumption [4,9,10]. Nevertheless, practical implementation of photocatalytic alcohol oxidation faces three fundamental challenges: (1) limited light absorption efficiency due to wide bandgap materials, (2) rapid charge carrier recombination impairing catalytic activity, and (3) insufficient selectivity control leading to over-oxidation products [10–15]. Defect engineering has recently emerged as a transformative strategy to address these limitations through precise manipulation of catalyst electronic structures [16–19]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2), a benchmark photocatalyst valued for its chemical stability, non-toxicity, and cost-effectiveness [20–22], demonstrates particular promise when modified through defect incorporation. Despite its extensive applications in environmental remediation and organic synthesis [23–25], intrinsic limitations of pristine TiO2—including a wide bandgap (3.0–3.2 eV) restricting UV-only activation, rapid electron-hole recombination, and propensity for aldehyde over-oxidation—have hindered its broader utilization [26–29]. Recent advances in defect-engineered TiO2 systems demonstrate remarkable progress in alcohol oxidation. Duan et al. achieved 88.3 % benzyl alcohol conversion using Pd/TiO2− x hollow spheres, where oxygen vacancies synergized with Pd nanoparticles to enhance charge separation under visible light [30]. She et al. further revealed that Ni-doped TiO2 with controlled oxygen defects utilizes peroxo groups as electron mediators, significantly improving benzaldehyde selectivity [18]. However, these studies also highlight the critical need for precise defect control, as exemplified by Pan et al.'s observation that excessive oxygen vacancies on {001}-faceted TiO2 nanocrystals paradoxically degrade photocatalytic performance [31]. This delicate balance between defect concentration and catalytic efficacy underscores the importance of developing controlled synthesis methodologies. In this study, we present a facile NaBH4 treatment protocol to engineer defect-rich TiO2 photocatalysts (denoted TiO2-2.5) for efficient selective alcohol oxidation. Systematic evaluation under 300 W xenon lamp irradiation demonstrates superior performance of TiO2-2.5, achieving 81.2 % benzyl alcohol conversion with high aldehyde selectivity—a 71 % enhancement over pristine TiO2. Through comprehensive mechanistic investigations, we propose that optimized oxygen vacancies facilitate both visible light absorption and charge separation while suppressing over-oxidation pathways. This work establishes a rational framework for defect engineering in TiO2-based photocatalysts and provides critical insights into structure-performance relationships for sustainable organic transformations. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Preparation of catalysts TiO2 was synthesized using the hydrothermal method with fluorine induction. In brief, 50 mL of tetrabutyl titanate, 6 mL of hydrofluoric acid, and 20 mL of hydrogen peroxide were placed in a 200 mL polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) stainless steel reactor, and the reactor was maintained at 180 °C for 24 h in an oven. The resulting solids were washed with a sodium hydroxide aqueous solution to remove fluoride ions (F−), and then washed with deionized water until the pH of the supernatant reached approximately 7. Finally, the produced solid particles were dried in an oven at 60 °C. To prepare the defective TiO2 samples, 100 mg of TiO2 was first dispersed in 20 ml of deionized water and stirred at room temperature for one hour. Next, 10 ml of NaBH4 solution at various concentrations (1.5, 2.5, and 4.0 mol/L) was added to the mixture. The solution was then continuously stirred for an additional 1.5 h and allowed to age for 3 h. After the aging process, the samples were subjected to centrifugal washing, first with water and then with ethanol. Finally, the washed samples were dried overnight at 60 °C. The resulting products were named TiO2-1.5, TiO2-2.5, and TiO2-4.0, corresponding to the different concentrations of NaBH4 used. 2.2 Materials characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD, Ultima IV-185, Rigaku) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was characterized for illustrating the phase structure of all samples. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100, Japan) was examined to analyze the morphology and high-resolution structure. The ultraviolet–visible solid diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) was determined using a UV-2600 spectrophotometer (Cary 5000 spectrometer). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific K-AlPHA+, US) was used to investigate the compositions and the chemical states of the elements of samples and the standard binding energy of C 1s is at 284.8 eV. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area, pore volume and the pore structure of the catalysts were measured on a Beshide 3H-2000PS2 adsorption apparatus, and the BET specific surface area was calculated from the data of N2 physisorption isotherms. PL spectra were measured using an Edinburgh Instruments FLS1000 equipped with a Xe lamp at room temperature under the excitation of 360 nm. Temperature-programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) experiments were performed with the Belcat-II apparatus, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The O2 gas was fed into the reactor with a flow rate of 50 mL/min at 50 °C for O2 adsorption before conducting the O2-TPD measurements. Finally, the temperature was increased from 50 to 650 °C at the ramping rate of 10 °C/min in He flow (50 mL/min). 2.3 Photocatalytic reaction The selective photocatalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol was conducted in a 25 mL round-bottom flask, with a 300 W Xenon arc lamp (model CEL-HXF300, supplied by Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd., China) serving as the light source. For a standard reaction, 40 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 4 mL of acetonitrile, along with 0.2 mmol of benzyl alcohol, within a 25 mL round-bottom flask. The reaction system's temperature was maintained at 25 °C using a water circulation device. The mixture was then subjected to ultraviolet–visible light irradiation in the presence of molecular oxygen and stirred for a duration of 6 h. Following the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the mixture using a Millipore filter with a pore size of 0.22 μm. The clear supernatant was subsequently analyzed by gas chromatography (model 7890B, Agilent) to determine the reaction outcomes. Additionally, the trapping experiments of radicals, holes and electronic were performed according to the established methods. For instance, 0.1 mmol of BQ was used as a superoxide radical (•O2 ‒) scavenger, 0.1 mmol of IPA was used as hydroxyl radical (•OH) scavenger, NaN3 and TEMPO as scavenger of singlet oxygen (1O2). EDTA-2Na and Mn(Ac)3 were used as a hole (h+), electron (e‒) trapping agent, respectively. 2.4 Photoelectrochemical measurements All photoelectrochemical experiments were conducted at ambient temperature using a CHI660E electrochemical workstation, equipped with a conventional three-electrode cell setup. An Ag/AgCl electrode served as the reference electrode, while a Pt wire was utilized as the counter electrode. The working electrodes were fabricated by depositing a mixture of 5 mg of photocatalyst and 0.5 mL of Nafion/ethanol solution onto a glassy carbon electrode with a 3.0 mm diameter. An aqueous solution of Na2SO4 (0.1 M) was employed as the electrolyte, and a Xe lamp provided visible light irradiation for the experiments. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed across a frequency range of 0.1 to 105 Hz, applying an alternating current voltage amplitude of 5 mV at a bias potential of 0.2 V against the Ag/AgCl electrode. Transient photocurrent measurements were conducted under light irradiation, starting from an initial voltage of 0.1 V. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphological characteristics In the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern shown in Fig. 1 a, all observed diffraction peaks perfectly correspond to the crystal structure of anatase TiO2 phase (space group I41/amd) [32]. In-depth analysis of the XRD spectrum (see Fig. 1b) reveals that the (101) diffraction peak of the TiO2-2.5 sample has shifted from the 2 θ position of 25.3° for the original TiO2 sample to 25.25°. According to Bragg-Brentano's law, this decrease in angle indicates an increase in the corresponding interplanar spacing [33]. This increase in interplanar spacing is due to a slight increase in the lattice parameters a and c, indicating an overall expansion of the unit cell after treatment with NaBH4. This expansion is likely due to lattice stress introduced during the treatment process, which leads to an increase in the atomic spacing within the lattice, causing the unit cell to expand in volume [34]. Lattice tensile stress can lead to the formation of defects in the crystal, such as vacancies, dislocations, and grain boundaries, which in turn can alter the material's absorption spectrum and band structure, thereby affecting the electron mobility and conductivity [35]. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis revealed that both TiO2 and NaBH4-treated TiO2-2.5 samples exhibited characteristic type IV isotherms (Fig. 2 ) according to IUPAC classification, confirming their mesoporous structure. Significantly, the presence of H3-type hysteresis loops in both samples indicates the pore structure of the TiO2-2.5 sample after NaBH4 treatment has not undergone significant alterations [36]. BET measurements showed a specific surface area of 90.8 m2/g for pristine TiO2, which slightly decreased to 83.7 m2/g after NaBH4 treatment. BJH pore size distribution analysis revealed a reduction in the most probable pore size from 2.5 nm to 2.1 nm. These moderate reductions in structural parameters may be associated with the contraction of some mesoporous structures and surface reconstruction during the NaBH4 treatment process. Despite the decrease in specific surface area and the most probable pore diameter, the defects induced by NaBH4 treatment in TiO2-2.5 may enhance the adsorption-desorption dynamics of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface, partially offsetting the reduction in the number of active sites, which provides a structural basis for the maintenance of subsequent photocatalytic performance. The morphology and dimensions of TiO2 and TiO2-2.5 were effectively elucidated through TEM and HRTEM analyses, as depicted in Fig. 3 (a–d). As observed in Fig. 3a and c, the TEM images reveal that both TiO2 and TiO2-2.5 consist of aggregates of irregular cubic nanoparticles, with the particles having an average size between 20 nm and 50 nm. The lattice planes seen in Fig. 3 measure 0.352 nm (101), closely aligning with the 0.3517 nm (101) plane and showing a good match with the ICDD card no. 01-78-2486. Following treatment with NaBH4, the lattice spacing of the (101) plane in TiO2-2.5 underwent an expansion from the initial 0.352 nm to 0.367 nm, as illustrated in Fig. 3d. This expansion is attributed to the strain induced by Ti4+ ions occupying the same lattice sites within the crystal structure [37]. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns shown in Fig. 3b-1 and d-1, obtained through inverse Fourier transformation, clearly indicate that the lattice of TiO2-2.5 experiences significant distortion post NaBH4 treatment. These distortions are indicative of alterations in bond lengths and other lattice parameters. XPS technology was used to investigate the chemical states and coordination environment on the surfaces of TiO2 and TiO2-2.5 samples. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the Ti 2p spectra of both samples exhibit two spin-orbit split peaks, Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2. The binding energy difference between these two peaks is nearly 5.7 eV, indicating that the titanium element primarily exists in the Ti4+ oxidation state [38,39]. In the TiO2-2.5 sample, the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 peaks shift to a lower binding energy direction by 0.2 eV compared to the unmodified TiO2 sample. This slight negative shift in binding energy is significant, revealing the existence of two distinct TiO2 entities and suggesting that the electron configuration of Ti in the TiO bond may have changed [39,40]. In the O 1s spectra shown in Fig. 4b, the dominant peak at approximately 529.5 eV is attributed to TiO bonding, while the broad and weak peak at around 531.2 eV corresponds to oxygen species associated with OH groups. Additionally, a characteristic peak of the possible presence of adsorbed water and organic pollutants at 533.1 eV is observed in the TiO2-2.5 sample [38,41]. Moreover, the O 1s spectrum of the TiO2-2.5 sample shows a shift to a higher binding energy direction by 0.1 eV compared to the unmodified TiO2 sample. These results indicate that the coordination environment of the elements in the TiO2-2.5 sample has changed after treatment with NaBH4. Fig. 4c shows that TiO2-2.5 has stronger absorption in the UV–visible range and exhibits a redshift in the band gap transition compared to TiO2. Moreover, according to the Tauc plot (inset of Fig. 4d), the band gaps of TiO2 and TiO2-2.5 are estimated to be 2.91 eV and 2.53 eV, respectively. This can be explained by the presence of lattice distortion (see Fig. 3), where the applied strain modifies the conduction band energy, thereby reducing the band gap [37,41–43]. Therefore, the more favorable electronic structure of the synthesized photocatalyst, with a lower band gap value than TiO2, significantly promotes efficient electron-hole excitation. 3.2 Photocatalytic performances and a plausible reaction mechanism To assess the impact of NaBH4-treated TiO2 on photocatalytic activity, the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) to benzaldehyde (BAD) was chosen as the model reaction. As depicted in Fig. 5 a, the conversion of BA to BAD is merely 47.5 % after 6 h using untreated TiO2. In contrast, the conversion significantly increases to 71.6 % when using TiO2-1.5. As the concentration of NaBH4 treatment increases, the highest yield of 81.2 % is achieved with TiO2-2.5. Subsequently, the yield decreases to 65.2 % for TiO2-4.0, which is still marginally higher than that of the untreated TiO2. Fig. 5b exhibits the photocatalytic reaction performance of BA on the TiO2-2.5 catalyst. The conversion rate of BA gradually increases with the extension of reaction time. The study finds that after 2 h, the conversion rate of BA reaches 53 %, with a selectivity for BAD of 98.7 %. When the reaction is extended to 6 h, the conversion rate of BA significantly increases to 81.2 %, with a selectivity for BAD of 99.3 %. In addition, Fig. 5c illustrates the photocatalytic activity of TiO2-2.5 under ultraviolet–visible light of varying intensities. As expected, the conversion rate of BA increases with the enhancement of light intensity. When the light intensity is increased from 100 to 300 mW/cm2, the conversion rate of BA rises from 52.1 % to 82.1 %, while the selectivity for BAD remains around 99 %. As shown in Fig. 5d, the BA conversion rate of the TiO2-2.5 catalyst dramatically decreased to 51 % after the first cycle, with no further significant decay observed in subsequent cycles. This suggests that the strong adsorption of the reaction product BAD likely caused deactivation by blocking active sites and pore channels. To validate this hypothesis, we conducted a two-stage regeneration experiment: (1) High-Temperature Oxidation: Spent catalysts after five cycles were calcined at 500 °C in air for 2 h to remove surface adsorbates. However, the regenerated sample (Run6a) showed only 48 % BA conversion, comparable to pristine TiO2, indicating that high-temperature treatment may degrade the defect structures or active sites in TiO2-2.5. (2) Secondary NaBH4 Reconstruction: Re-treatment of Run6a with NaBH₄ restoration significantly recovered BA conversion to 81 % (Run7b) while maintaining >99 % BAD selectivity. These results demonstrate that: (1) The primary deactivation mechanism involves specific chemical adsorption of BAD at active sites rather than structural collapse. (2) NaBH4 treatment reconstructs surface oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ centers, restoring electron transport capability. (3) Thermal oxidation alone removes organics but requires subsequent reductive treatment to regenerate active surface configurations. This regeneration strategy elucidates the physicochemical nature of the deactivation mechanism and provides a critical methodology for designing recyclable photocatalytic systems. To investigate the reason for the performance degradation of TiO2-2.5 during the cyclic use in the photocatalytic selective oxidation of BA, the phase and surface chemical environment of the sample before and after the reaction were characterized. As can be seen from the XRD pattern in Fig. 6 a, there was no significant change in the phase of the catalyst before and after the reaction, indicating that the phase of the catalyst did not change. Similarly, no significant changes were observed in the Ti 2p spectrum before and after the reaction (Fig. 6b), indicating that the coordination environment of Ti on the catalyst surface also did not undergo significant changes. However, compared to TiO2-2.5 (fresh), the O1s spectrum of TiO2-2.5 (Used) showed a clear shift to lower binding energy, suggesting that other oxygen-containing species were adsorbed on the surface of TiO2-2.5 after the reaction (Fig. 6c). BA-TPD and BAD-TPD were used to explore the adsorption strength of BA and BAD on the surface of TiO2-2.5. As can be seen from Fig. 6d, TiO2-2.5 has a stronger adsorption energy for BAD. These results indicate that although TiO2-2.5 has good photocatalytic performance for the selective oxidation of BA, it has a stronger adsorption strength for the reaction product BAD, leading to the adsorption of the product BAD on the surface of the catalyst. This covers some of the active sites, resulting in a decrease in catalyst activity. Entry 1 in Table 1 , reveals that the conversion of benzyl alcohol (BA) under light alone, without a catalyst, was minimal at 2.6 %, indicating virtually no conversion. The addition of a catalyst, however, dramatically increased the conversion rate to 81.2 % in an O2 atmosphere, highlighting the significance of TiO2-2.5 in the selective oxidation of BA to BAD. A control experiment without light confirmed that the oxidation of BA over TiO2-2.5 is a light-driven process, as the conversion was negligible in the dark. Entries 3 to 5 were dedicated to fine-tuning the catalyst amount, identifying 40 mg as the optimal loading for this reaction. Comparing Entries 6 and 7, it became evident that the conversion rates under air and N2 were lower than under O2, suggesting that the O2 concentration plays a key role in determining the catalyst's performance. Table 2 displays the photocatalytic oxidation reaction efficacy of various substituted aromatic alcohols on the TiO2-2.5 catalyst. The research findings indicate that regardless of whether benzyl alcohol is modified with electron-donating substituents (such as CH3, OCH3) or electron-withdrawing substituents (such as Cl), it can be efficiently converted into the corresponding aldehydes under UV–visible light irradiation, with a conversion rate exceeding 90 %. These data highlight the broad applicability and high efficiency of TiO2-2.5 in the transformation of specific functional groups. In order to gain a deeper understanding of the photocatalytic mechanism of BA selective oxidation in the TiO2-2.5 system and to comprehend the role of photogenerated holes and radicals in the photocatalytic process, charge trapping studies were conducted. To investigate the role of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the photocatalytic activity of TiO2-2.5 was significantly inhibited by the addition of EDTA-2Na, Mn(Ac)3, benzoquinone (BQ), and isopropanol (IPA) as model scavengers to capture holes (h+), electrons (e−), superoxide radical (·O2 −), and hydroxyl radical (·OH), respectively [44–46]. Fig. 7 a shows the performance of TiO2-2.5 for the selective oxidation of BA in the presence of various scavengers. The inhibitory effects of BQ, EDTA-2Na, and Mn(Ac)3 on the selective oxidation of BA were stronger than that of IPA, indicating that ·O2 −, h+, and e− are the primary active species in the selective oxidation of BA under the TiO2-2.5 catalytic system. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy, using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) [47], has been applied to measure the active reactive radical intermediates during the reaction process. Under light irradiation, the ·O2 − radical was observed (Fig. 7b), indicating that photogenerated electrons under light irradiation are sufficient to form superoxide radicals. In the dark conditions, no ·O2 − was detected, further demonstrating that the ·O2 − indeed plays a key role in the photocatalytic selective oxidation of BA by TiO2-2.5. In order to deeply investigate the charge transport behavior on the surfaces of TiO2 and TiO2-2.5, an estimation of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted. It is widely recognized that a smaller radius of the first semicircle indicates a decrease in electron-transfer resistance (the low-frequency semicircle), which implies a higher efficiency of separation and charge transfer [46,48–51]. Compared to TiO2, TiO2-2.5 shows a higher separation efficiency of photoinduced e−/h+ pairs, faster interfacial charge transfer, and more efficient separation of electron-hole pairs (Fig. 7c) [52,53]. To further elucidate the ability of TiO2 and TiO2-2.5 to promote photoinduced electron-hole separation efficiency, the transient photocurrent response under xenon lamp during ON/OFF cycles was studied. As shown in Fig. 7d, when the light was turned on, the photocurrent increased immediately; when the light was turned off, the photocurrent decreased rapidly [54–56]. The results indicate that among the composites prepared in this work, TiO2 has the highest charge carrier recombination rate. On the other hand, the measurement results show that the transient photocurrent density of the TiO2-2.5 catalyst is higher than that of the TiO2 catalyst, suggesting that its ability to separate electrons and holes is stronger. It is clear that the results of the photocurrent and EIS are consistent. Based on the above experimental results, a reasonable mechanism is proposed to explain the photocatalytic oxidation process of BA on TiO2-2.5, as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Under visible light irradiation, electrons are excited from the valence band (VB) of TiO2-2.5 to its conduction band (CB), and the band gap of TiO2-2.5 is narrowed due to the presence of lattice stress, which is beneficial for the excitation of electrons and holes. Moreover, lattice strain affects the chemical coordination environment of the surface elements of TiO2-2.5, promoting the separation of electrons and holes. Subsequently, the electrons are captured by the adsorbed oxygen to form·O2 − radicals. Both ·O2 − radicals and holes participate in the oxidation reaction from BA to BAD. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a simple NaBH4 treatment was employed to successfully fabricate the TiO2-x photocatalyst for the photo-oxidation of BA to synthesize BAD. Studies have shown that, compared to TiO2, the prepared TiO2-2.5 significantly reduces the energy barrier required for electron excitation, thereby enhancing the photoexcitation of electrons in the valence band. Meanwhile, the formation of lattice stress in TiO2-2.5 alters the chemical coordination environment of the surface elements of the catalyst, accelerating the separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers. Therefore, TiO2-2.5 significantly improves the catalytic performance for the photocatalytic oxidation of BA to synthesize BAD. This work provides new insights into the mechanism of BA transformation on the TiO2-2.5 catalyst and contributes to the design of more efficient catalysts for the photocatalytic oxidation of BA. coredata.dc:description: Lattice stress modulation is an effective means to regulate the photocatalytic performance of materials. In this study, the TiO2-2.5 photocatalyst was successfully prepared using a simple NaBH4 treatment method, and its photocatalytic activity in the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) to benzaldehyde (BAD) was investigated. The results showed that compared to untreated TiO2, TiO2-2.5 significantly increases the conversion rate of BA to BAD up to 81.2 % within 6 h under the irradiation of a 300 W xenon lamp. Analysis by XRD, TEM, XPS, and UV–vis DRS revealed that the NaBH4 treatment introduced lattice stress and defects, altering the electronic structure and surface chemical environment of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its photocatalytic performance. Moreover, the decrease in activity of TiO2-2.5 during cyclic use is attributed to the strong adsorption of the reaction product BAD on the catalyst surface, which covers some of the active sites. This study provides valuable information for the defect regulation and photocatalytic performance enhancement of TiO2-based catalysts.
